clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Sucrose on Pain Relief During Venous Blood Sampling in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Sucrose on Pain Relief During Venous Blood Sampling in Preterm Infants: a Comparison of Two Different Doses

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

collaborator.agency: Lower Umfolozi Regional War Memorial Hospital

clinical_study.source: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock: Despite the fact that oral sucrose is the most frequently studied non-pharmacological intervention for procedural pain relief in infants, there is a paucity of data on the minimal effective dose. The aim of this study is to find the minimal effective dose of sucrose to reduce pain during a single venous blood sampling procedure.

primary_outcome.description: assessed by Premature Infant Pain Profile-Revised (PIPP-R). Pain score related to the blood sampling will be performed two times: at skin puncture and immediately after the needle has been removed

arm_group.description: on 2 occasions within 1 week 0.2 ml sucrose 25% or 0.5 ml sucrose 25% will be given in randomized order to the same infant during blood sampling
on 2 occasions within 1 week 0.2 ml sucrose 25% or 0.5 ml sucrose 25% will be given in randomized order to the same infant during blood sampling

intervention.description: Administered on the tongue by a syringe, a half dose two minutes before blood sampling and the other half dose immediately before sampling
Administered on the tongue by a syringe, a half dose two minutes before blood sampling and the other half dose immediately before sampling

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- born preterm
- more than 1000 gram
Exclusion Criteria:
- severe intraventricular hemorrhage
- cerebral malformations
- other malformations requiring surgery
- medication that may impair pain expression (opioids, paracetamol, sedatives)
